{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} [[Image:ReleasetheColombia3.JPG|thumb|right|A Sinn Féin poster calling for the men's release]] The '''Colombia Three''' are three individuals – Niall Connolly, James Monaghan and Martin McCauley – who are currently living in the [[Republic of Ireland]], having fled from [[Colombia]], where they were sentenced to prison terms of seventeen years for training [[FARC]] rebels. The incident came during a crucial time in the [[Northern Ireland peace process]] and risked damaging it.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2001/aug/18/colombia.northernireland</ref>
==Arrest== The three came to prominence on 11 August 2001, when they were arrested travelling on false passports at [[Bogotá International Airport]] while waiting to transfer to international flights out of the country. The Colombian authorities alleged at the time that they were training [[FARC]] rebels and were members of the [[Provisional Irish Republican Army]] (IRA).<ref>{{cite web | title = Suspected IRA member charged in Colombia | url = http://www.rte.ie/news/2001/0815/ira.html | publisher = ''RTÉ'' | date = 15 August 2001 | accessdate = 12 February 2007}}</ref> According to General [[Fernando Tapias Stahelin]], the Colombian authorities were tipped off by "an international security organisation".<ref name="mult2">{{cite news | title = Suspected IRA trio held in Colombia | url = https://www.theguardian.com/colombia/story/0,,630743,00.html | publisher = ''[[The Guardian]]'' | date = 14 August 2001 | accessdate = 12 February 2007 | location=London | first=Martin | last=Hodgson}}</ref>
Two of the three men, Monaghan and McCauley, had arrived in [[Colombia]] on 30 June 2001 on a flight from [[Belfast]], via Paris. Niall Connolly had flown from [[Dublin]], via [[Madrid]], and spent a day in [[Caracas]] before making a rendezvous in [[Bogotá]]. The three men then spent the next five weeks travelling through a demilitarised southern zone of Colombia, then under the control of the FARC rebels as part of peace talks with the Colombian government.<ref name="mult1"/> They were arrested as soon as they touched down in Bogotá on a commercial flight on the Saturday night.<ref>{{cite news | title = Cuba link to Colombia IRA suspect | author = Daniel Schweimler | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/1496948.stm | publisher = ''[[BBC News]]'' | date = 17 August 2001 | accessdate = 12 February 2007}}</ref>
==Prosecution== After the men's arrest at Bogota airport, they were only charged with travelling on false passports, until 15 February 2002, when they were also charged with training FARC rebels in bomb-making.<ref>{{cite news | title = 'IRA three' charged by Colombians | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/1825029.stm | publisher = ''BBC News'' | date = 16 February 2002 | accessdate = 12 February 2007}}</ref> After a number of delays, including a boycott of proceedings by the three accused, the trial opened on 2 December 2002.<ref>{{cite news | title = Trial of IRA men begins today | author = Ruth Morris | url = https://www.theguardian.com/colombia/story/0,,852087,00.html | publisher = ''The Guardian'' | date = 2 December 2002 | accessdate = 12 February 2007 | location=London}}</ref> Following a number of adjournments, the trial closed on 1 August 2003.<ref>{{cite news | title = Irish trio await Bogota verdict | author = Sibylla Brodzinsky | url = https://www.theguardian.com/colombia/story/0,,1011064,00.html | publisher = ''The Guardian'' | date = 2 August 2003 | accessdate = 12 February 2007 | location=London}}</ref> The trial judge returned a verdict which found the three men guilty of travelling on false passports and they were given varying sentences of up to 44 months. They were found not guilty on the more serious charges relating to training FARC rebels; however, the judge ordered their release upon payment of fines equivalent to £3,800.<ref>{{cite news | title = Colombia clears IRA suspects | author = Sibylla Brodzinsky | url = https://www.theguardian.com/colombia/story/0,,1204238,00.html | publisher = ''The Guardian'' | date = 27 April 2004 | accessdate = 12 February 2007 | location=London}}</ref>
==Appeal== In accordance with Colombian law, the prosecution had the right to appeal the verdict, which it did. While awaiting appeal, the three men were free to leave jail, but were instructed by a judge to remain within the country. The appeal court overturned the original trial verdict, and convicted the men of training the rebels, sentencing them to seventeen years in jail on 16 December 2004.<ref>{{cite news | title = Irishmen in hiding jailed for 17 years | author = Sibylla Brodzinsky | url = https://www.theguardian.com/colombia/story/0,,1375729,00.html | publisher = ''The Guardian'' | date = 17 December 2004 | accessdate = 12 February 2007 | location=London}}</ref>
==Return to Ireland== The day after their conviction, the [[Attorney General of Colombia|Colombian Attorney General]] announced that the men had fled Colombia.<ref>{{cite news | title = Irish trio 'have fled Colombia' | author = Sibylla Brodzinsky | url = https://www.theguardian.com/colombia/story/0,,1376619,00.html | publisher = ''The Guardian'' | date = 18 December 2004 | accessdate = 12 February 2007 | location=London}}</ref> On 5 August 2005, following an interview with Monaghan by [[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]'s [[Charlie Bird]], it emerged that the three men had clandestinely returned to Ireland.<ref>{{cite news | title = Colombian 3 back in Ireland | author = Angelique Chrisafis | url = https://www.theguardian.com/colombia/story/0,,1543586,00.html | publisher = ''The Guardian'' | date = 6 August 2005 | accessdate = 12 February 2007 | location=London}}</ref> The three men were subsequently questioned by [[Garda Síochána|Gardaí]] but no moves have been taken in relation to extraditing them to Colombia, despite the existence of a Colombian [[arrest warrant]], since no extradition treaty or agreement exists between Colombia and Ireland.<ref>{{cite news | title = Irish police question Colombia Three | author = Sophie Kirkham | url = https://www.theguardian.com/colombia/story/0,,1552015,00.html | publisher = ''The Guardian'' | date = 19 August 2005 | accessdate = 12 February 2007 | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Interpol members told of warrant | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/4172421.stm | publisher = ''BBC News'' | date = 14 January 2005 | accessdate = 12 February 2007}}</ref>
==The Colombia Three== ===James Monaghan=== [[File:ColombiaThreeBadge.JPG|thumb|right|A badge calling for the release of the Colombia Three]] James William Monaghan was born on 9 August 1945, and is originally from [[County Donegal]] but his last known address was in [[Newry]], [[County Down]]. <ref name="mult4"/><ref name="mult5">{{cite web | title = Explosive Journey: Perceptions of Latin America in the FARC-IRA Affair (2001–2005) | author = Edmundo Murray | url = http://www.irlandeses.org/21stC1.htm | publisher = ''Society for Irish Latin American Studies'' | date = 1 March 2006 | accessdate = 13 February 2007}}</ref> In the 1970s he was believed to have been active in the IRA, gaining the nickname 'Mortar' on account of his skill in manufacturing [[barrack buster|homemade mortars]] and,<ref>{{cite web|title=Globalizing Terrorism: The FARC-IRA Connection |author=Mark Burgess |url=http://www.cdi.org/terrorism/farc-ira-pr.cfm |publisher=''Center for Defence Information'' |date=5 June 2002 |accessdate=13 February 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070214103404/http://www.cdi.org/terrorism/farc-ira-pr.cfm |archivedate=14 February 2007 |df= }}</ref> according to security sources, he was head of the IRA's engineering section.<ref name="mult3"/>
Monaghan was arrested on terrorist charges in County Donegal in the 1970s.<ref name="mult4"/> In 1972 he was arrested in London and given a prison sentence for terrorism offences.<ref name="mult5"/> In 1976, he escaped from the [[Special Criminal Court]] in Dublin following a double bomb blast.<ref name="mult4"/> He was elected to the [[Sinn Féin]] Ard Chomhairle in 1989. According to [[Alex Maskey]], he left Sinn Féin in 1989 or 1990,<ref>{{cite news | title = Colombian investigation continues | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/1493778.stm | publisher = ''BBC News'' | date = 16 August 2001 | accessdate = 14 February 2007}}</ref> In 1999 he joined an organisation called [[Coiste na n-Iarchimí]], a Republican ex-prisoners group.<ref name="mult5"/> He was reported to have been a member of the [[IRA Army Council]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Irish police identify 'IRA suspect' | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/1490106.stm | publisher = ''BBC News'' | date = 14 August 2001 | accessdate = 12 February 2007}}</ref>
===Martin McCauley===
Martin McCauley was born on 1 December 1962 in [[County Armagh]].<ref name="mult5"/> He was shot aged 19 in 1982 by the [[Royal Ulster Constabulary]] (RUC) in a barn near [[Lurgan]] resulting from which he won a five-figure sum for damages against the RUC. He was unarmed at the time and another teenager was killed. In 1985 he was charged with weapons possession in [[Northern Ireland]] and received a two-year [[suspended sentence]].<ref name="mult3"/> He was a Sinn Féin election worker during assembly elections in the [[Upper Bann (Assembly constituency)|Upper Bann]] constituency in 1998, but according to Sinn Féin he was not a member of the party.<ref name="mult4">{{cite news | title = Who are IRA suspects? | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/1494880.stm | publisher = ''BBC News'' | date = 17 August 2001 | accessdate = 12 February 2007}}</ref> McCauley is regarded as a leading figure in the IRA's engineering section.<ref name="mult1"/>
===Niall Connolly===
Niall Connolly was born on 5 December 1964<ref name="mult5"/> in [[Glenageary]], [[County Dublin]], and was educated at [[Newpark Comprehensive School]]<ref>{{cite news | title = The self-sacrificing Niall Connolly I knew | url = http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/the-selfsacrificing-niall-connolly-i-knew-26250290.html | publisher = 'Irish Independent | date = 19 August 2001 | accessdate = 22 January 2015 | location=Dublin | first=Michael | last=Sheridan}}</ref> and [[Trinity College, Dublin]].<ref name="mult1">{{cite news | title = IRA blunder in the jungle sparks US rage | url = https://www.theguardian.com/Northern_Ireland/Story/0,,539230,00.html | publisher = ''The Guardian'' | date = 19 August 2001 | accessdate = 12 February 2007 | location=London | first=Martin | last=Hodgson}}</ref> The only one of the three who was a fluent [[Spanish language|Spanish]] speaker, he has extensive experience in Latin America, having worked there for a number of years.<ref name="mult3">{{cite news | title = Qualified in terrorism | author = Rosie Cowan | url = https://www.theguardian.com/Northern_Ireland/Story/0,,537147,00.html | publisher = ''The Guardian'' | date = 15 August 2001 | accessdate = 12 February 2007 | location=London}}</ref> Prior to his arrest, he was resident in [[Cuba]], where the Cuban authorities claimed he was the Latin America representative for Sinn Féin.<ref name="mult1"/> This was initially denied by Sinn Féin, but they later accepted that he had been working in Cuba as a part-time party representative.<ref>{{cite news | title = Sinn Féin urges IRA to disarm | author = Matthew Tempest| url = https://www.theguardian.com/Northern_Ireland/Story/0,,578792,00.html | publisher = ''The Guardian'' | date = 22 October 2001 | accessdate = 12 February 2007 | location=London}}</ref>

{{external links|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox U.S. legislation | othershorttitles= Sonny Bono Copyright Term Extension Act, Sonny Bono Act | fullname= To amend the provisions of title 17, United States Code, with respect to the duration of copyright, and for other purposes. | nickname= Mickey Mouse Protection Act | acronym= CTEA | enacted by= 105th | effective date= October 27, 1998 | public law url= | cite public law= {{USPL|105|298}} | cite statutes at large= {{USStat|112|2827}} | acts amended= [[Copyright Act of 1976]] | title amended= 17 (Copyrights) | sections created= | sections amended= 17 U.S.C. §§ 108, 203(a)(2), 301(c), 302, 303, 304(c)(2) | leghisturl= http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d105:SN00505:@@@S | introducedin= Senate | introducedbill= {{USBill|105|S|505}} | introducedby= [[Orrin Hatch]] | introduceddate= March 20, 1997 | committees= | passedbody1= Senate | passeddate1= October 7, 1998 | passedvote1= [[unanimous consent]] | passedbody2= House | passeddate2= October 7, 1998 | passedvote2= [[voice vote]] | signedpresident= [[Bill Clinton]] | signeddate= October 27, 1998 | amendments= | SCOTUS cases= ''[[Eldred v. Ashcroft]]'' }}
[[Image:Tom Bell's graph showing extension of U.S. copyright term over time.svg|thumb|right|450px|Expansion of U.S. copyright law (assuming authors create their works 35 years before their death)]]
The '''Copyright Term Extension Act''' ('''CTEA''') of 1998 extended [[United States copyright law|copyright]] [[copyright term|terms]] in the [[United States]]. It is one of several acts extending the terms of copyrights.<ref>https://www.copyright.gov/circs/circ15a.pdf</ref>
Following the [[Copyright Act of 1976]], [[copyright]] would last for the life of the author plus 50 years, or 75 years for a work of [[corporate authorship]]. The 1976 Act also increased the extension term for works copyrighted before 1978 that had not already entered the public domain from 28 years to 47 years, giving a total term of 75 years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.copyright.gov/pr/pdomain.html|title=U.S. Copyright Office - Certain Unpublished, Unregistered Works Enter Public Domain|last=(www.copyright.gov)|first=U.S. Copyright Office|website=www.copyright.gov|access-date=2018-01-14}}</ref>
The 1998 Act extended these terms to life of the author plus 70 years and for works of corporate authorship to 120 years after creation or 95 years after publication, whichever end is earlier.<ref>U.S. Copyright Office, Circular 1: [http://www.copyright.gov/circs/circ01.pdf Copyright Basics], pp. 5–6</ref> Copyright protection for works published before January 1, 1978, was increased by 20 years to a total of 95 years from their publication date.
This law, also known as the '''[[Sonny Bono]] Copyright Term Extension Act''', '''Sonny Bono Act''', or (derisively) the '''[[Mickey Mouse]] Protection Act''',{{r|lessig}} effectively "froze" the advancement date of the [[public domain in the United States]] for works covered by the older fixed term copyright rules. Under this Act, works made in 1923 or afterwards that were still protected by copyright in 1998 will not enter the public domain until 2019 or later. Mickey Mouse specifically, having first appeared in 1928, will be in a public domain work in 2024<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://copyright.nova.edu/mickey-public-domain/|title=Mickey’s Headed to the Public Domain! But Will He Go Quietly? - Office of Copyright|date=2014-10-17|work=Office of Copyright|access-date=2018-01-14|language=en-US}}</ref> or afterward (depending on the date of the product) unless the owner of the copyright releases them into the public domain before then. Unlike [[Copyright law of the European Union#Duration of protection|copyright extension legislation in the European Union]], the Sonny Bono Act did not revive copyrights that had already expired. The Act did extend the terms of protection set for works that were already copyrighted, and is retroactive in that sense. However, works created before January 1, 1978, but not published or registered for copyright until recently, are addressed in a special section ({{USC|17|303}}) and may remain protected until the end of 2047. The Act became {{USPL|105|298}} on October 27, 1998.
== Background == Under the international [[Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works]] of 1886, the signatory countries are required to provide copyright protection for a minimum term of the life of the author plus fifty years. Additionally, they are permitted to provide for a longer term of protection. The Berne Convention did not come into force for the [[United States]] until it was ratified on March 1, 1989, but the U.S. had previously provided for the minimum copyright term the convention required in the [[Copyright Act of 1976]].
After the United States' accession to the Berne convention, a number of copyright owners successfully [[lobbying|lobbied]] the [[Congress of the United States|U.S. Congress]] for another extension of the term of copyright, to provide for the same term of protection that exists in [[Europe]]. Since the 1993 [[Directive on harmonising the term of copyright protection]], member states of the [[European Union]] implemented protection for a term of the author's life plus seventy years.
The act was named in memory of the late Congressman [[Sonny Bono]], who died nine months before the act became law: he had previously been one of twelve sponsors of a similar bill.
House members sympathetic to restaurant and bar owners, who were upset over [[ASCAP]] and [[Broadcast Music Incorporated|BMI]] licensing practices, almost derailed the Act. As a result, the bill was amended to include the [[Fairness in Music Licensing Act of 1998|Fairness in Music Licensing Act]], which exempted smaller establishments from needing a public performance license to play music.<ref>[[William Patry]], 1 ''Patry on Copyright'' § 1:97 (Thomson Reuters/West 2009)</ref>
Both houses of the United States Congress passed the act as Public Law 105-298 with a [[voice vote]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d105:HR02589:@@@X |title=THOMAS: Status of H.R. 2589 |publisher=Thomas.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=2011-01-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d105:SN00505:@@@X |title=THOMAS: Status of S. 505 |publisher=Thomas.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=2011-01-21}}</ref> President [[Bill Clinton]] signed the Sonny Bono Copyright Term Extension Act of 1998 on October 27, 1998.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.copyright.gov/reports/annual/2002/litigation.html |title=U.S. Copyright Office: Annual Report 2002: Litigation |publisher=Copyright.gov |date= |accessdate=2011-01-21}}</ref>
== Political climate ==
=== Senate Report 104-315 ===
The Senate Report<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/cpquery/R?cp104:FLD010:@1(sr315) |title=Senate Report 104-315 |publisher=Thomas.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=2011-01-21}}</ref> gave the official reasons for passing copyright extension laws and was originally written in the context of the Copyright Term Extension Act of 1995.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/104th-congress/senate-bill/483 |title=S.483 - Copyright Term Extension Act of 1996 |publisher=Congress.gov |date=1996-07-10 |accessdate=2014-12-15}}</ref>
{{quote|The purpose of the bill is to ensure adequate copyright protection for American works in foreign nations and the continued economic benefits of a healthy surplus [[balance of trade]] in the exploitation of copyrighted works. The bill accomplishes these goals by extending the current U.S. copyright term for an additional 21 years. Such an extension will provide significant trade benefits by substantially harmonizing U.S. copyright law to that of the European Union while ensuring fair compensation for American creators who deserve to benefit fully from the exploitation of their works. Moreover, by stimulating the creation of new works and providing enhanced economic incentives to preserve existing works, such an extension will enhance the long-term volume, vitality and accessibility of the public domain.}}
The authors of the report believed that extending copyright protection would help the United States by providing more protection for their works in foreign countries and by giving more incentive to digitize and preserve works since there was an exclusive right in them. The report also included minority opinions by [[Herbert Kohl (senator)|Herb Kohl]] and [[Hank Brown]], who believed that the term extensions were a financial windfall to current owners of copyrighted material at the expense of the public's use of the material.
=== Support === Since 1990, [[The Walt Disney Company]] had lobbied for copyright extension.{{r|dlobby1|dlobby2}} The legislation delayed the entry into the public domain of the earliest [[Mickey Mouse]] movies, leading detractors to the nickname "The Mickey Mouse Protection Act".{{r|lessig}}
In addition to Disney, California congresswoman [[Mary Bono Mack|Mary Bono]] (Sonny Bono's widow and Congressional successor), and the estate of composer [[George Gershwin]] supported the act. Mary Bono, speaking on the floor of the [[United States House of Representatives]], said:
{{quote|Actually, Sonny wanted the term of copyright protection to last forever. I am informed by staff that such a change would violate the [[Copyright Clause|Constitution]]. ... As you know, there is also <nowiki>[then-</nowiki>[[Motion Picture Association of America|MPAA]] president<nowiki>]</nowiki> [[Jack Valenti]]'s proposal for <!-- "the" is not in the quote here --> term to last forever less one day. Perhaps the Committee may look at that next Congress.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getpage.cgi?dbname=1998_record&position=all&page=H9952|date=October 7, 1998|publisher=[[United States Government Printing Office|Government Printing Office]]|accessdate=2007-10-30|work=[[Congressional Record]]|title=H9952}}</ref>}}
Other parties that lobbied in favor of the Bono Act were [[Time Warner]], [[Universal Pictures|Universal]], [[Viacom]], the major professional sports leagues ([[NFL]], [[NBA]], [[NHL]], [[MLB]]), and the family of slain singer [[Selena Quintanilla-Pérez]].{{r|dlobby1|dlobby2}}
Proponents of the Bono Act argue that it is necessary given that the [[life expectancy]] of humans has risen dramatically since Congress passed the original [[Copyright Act of 1790]],<ref name=Orr>{{cite web | title= Senator Orrin Hatch’s Introduction of The Copyright Term Extension Act of 1997 | url=http://www.copyrightextension.com/page04.html | date= 1997-03-20}}</ref> that a difference in copyright terms between the United States and Europe would negatively affect the international operations of the [[entertainment industry]],<ref name="Orr"/><ref name=Fein>{{cite web | title=Senator Dianne Feinstein's Statement before Congress | url=http://www.copyrightextension.com/page06.html | date=1997-03-20}}</ref> and that some works would be created under a longer copyright that would never be created under the existing copyright. They also claim that copyrighted works are an important source of income to the US<ref name="Fein"/><ref name=Leh>{{cite web | title= Excerpts of Bruce A. Lehman’s statement before Congress | url= http://www.copyrightextension.com/page07.html | date= 1995-09-20}}</ref> and that media such as [[VHS]], [[DVD]], [[Cable television|Cable]] and [[Satellite]] have increased the value and commercial life of movies and television series.<ref name="Fein"/>
Proponents contend that Congress has the power to pass whatever copyright term it wants because the language "To promote the progress of science and useful arts" in the United States Constitution is not a substantive limitation on the powers of Congress, leaving the sole restriction that copyrights must only last for "limited times." However, in what respect the granted time must be limited has never been determined, thus arguably even an absurdly long, yet finite, duration would still be a valid ''limited time'' according to the letter of the Constitution as long as Congress was ostensibly setting this limit to promote the progress of science and useful arts. This was one of the arguments that prevailed in the ''[[Eldred v. Ashcroft]]'' case, when the Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of the CTEA. It is also pointed out by proponents that the extension did not prevent all works from going in the public domain. They note that the 1976 Copyright Act established that [[unpublished]] works created before 1978 would still begin entering the public domain January 1, 2003 (Known author: life of the author plus 70 years; anonymous/pseudoanonymous/unknown author/works-for-hire: 120 years from creation), and that the provision remained unaffected by the 1998 extension.<ref name="Scott"/> They also claim that Congress has actually increased the scope of the public domain since, for the first time, unpublished works will enter the public domain.<ref name="Scott"/>
Proponents believe that copyright encourages progress in the arts. With an extension of copyright, future artists have to create something original, rather than reuse old work, however, had the act been in place in the 1960s, it is unlikely that [[Andy Warhol]] would have been able to sell or even exhibit any of his work, since it all incorporated previously copyrighted material. Proponents contend that it is more important to encourage all creators to make new works instead of just copyright holders.<ref name=Scott>{{cite journal| author = Scott M. Martin | date = September 24, 2002 | title = The Mythology of the Public Domain: Exploring the Myths Behind Attacks on the Duration of Copyright Protection | journal = Loyola of Los Angeles Law Review | volume = 36| issue = 1| page = 280| publisher = Loyola Law Review| issn = 1533-5860 | url = http://digitalcommons.lmu.edu/llr/vol36/iss1/7/ | accessdate = 2007-11-17}}</ref>
Proponents say that copyright better preserves intellectual property like movies, music and television shows.<ref name="Leh"/><ref name="Scott"/> One example given is the case of the classic film ''[[It's a Wonderful Life]]''.<ref name="Leh"/> Before [[Republic Pictures]] and [[Spelling Entertainment]] (who owned the motion picture rights to the short story and the music even after the film itself became public domain) began to assert their rights to the film, various local TV stations and cable networks broadcast the film endlessly. As ''[[The New York Times|New York Times]]'' reporter Bill Carter put it: "the film's currency was being devalued."<ref>{{cite news | title = THE MEDIA BUSINESS; Television | work = New York Times | date = 1994-12-19 | first = Bill | last = Carter | pages = D10| id = | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1994/12/19/business/the-media-business-television.html?scp=3&sq=tyrone+power&st=nyt | accessdate = 2010-11-27}}</ref>
Many different versions of the film were made and most if not all were in horrible condition.<ref>''See Two Days of Christmas Classics'', TORONTO STAR, December 24, 1999, At E1.</ref> After underlying rights to the film were enforced, it was given a high quality restoration that was hailed by critics. In addition, proponents note that once a work falls into the public domain there is no guarantee that the work will be more widely available or cheaper. Suggesting that quality copies of public domain works are not widely available, they argue that one reason for a lack of availability may be due to publishers' reluctance to publish a work that is in the public domain for fear that they will not be able to recoup their investment or earn enough profit.<ref name="Leh"/>
Proponents reject the idea that only works in the public domain can provide artistic inspiration. They note that opponents fail to take into account that copyright applies only to expressions of ideas and not the ideas themselves.<ref name="Scott"/> Thus artists are free to get ideas from copyrighted works as long as they do not [[copyright infringement|infringe]]. Borrowing ideas and such are common in film, TV and music even with copyrighted works (see ''[[scènes à faire]]'', [[idea-expression divide]] and [[stock character]]). Works such as [[parody]] benefit from [[fair use]].
Proponents also question the idea that extended copyright is "corporate welfare." They state that many opponents also have a stake in the case, claiming that those arguing against copyright term extension are mostly businesses that depend on distributing films and videos that have lost their copyright.<ref name="Leh"/>
One argument against the CTEA is focused on the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]]. In ''[[Harper & Row v. Nation Enterprises]]'', however, the court explained how a copyright "respects and adequately safeguards the [[freedom of speech]] protected by the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]]."<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://repository.jmls.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1025&context=ripl|title=Mickey Mouse & Sonny Bonno Go to Court: The Copyright Term Extension Act and its Effect on Current and Future Rights|last=Grzelak|first=Victoria A.|date=2002|website=|access-date=May 25, 2017}}</ref> In following this approach, courts have held that copyrights are "categorically immune from challenges under the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]]."<ref name=":0" />
=== Opposition === Critics of the CTEA argue that it was never the original intention for copyright protection to be extended in the United States. Attorney [https://www.robbinsarroyo.com/jenny-l-dixon/ Jenny L. Dixon] mentions that "the United States has always viewed copyright primarily as a vehicle for achieving social benefit based on the belief that encouragement of individual effort by personal gain is the best way to advance the public welfare;"<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://heinonline.org/HOL/Page?handle=hein.journals/hascom18&div=44&g_sent=1&collection=journals|title=The Copyright Term Extension Act: Is Life Plus Seventy Too Much|last=Dixon|first=Jenny L.|date=|website=|access-date=May 26, 2017}}</ref> however, "the U.S. does not consider copyright as a 'natural right.'"<ref name=":1" /> Dixon continues that with increased extensions on copyright protections, authors receive the benefits, while the public have more difficulty accessing these works, weakening public domain.<ref name=":1" /> One such extension Dixon mentions is the protection of a copyrighted work for the author's life followed by two generations, which opponents argue that there is no legislation nor intention for this copyright protection.<ref name=":1" /> "These constitutionally-grounded arguments 'for limitations on proprietary rights' are being rejected time and time again."<ref name=":1" />
[[Dennis S. Karjala]], a law professor, led an effort to try to prevent the CTEA from being passed. He testified before the Committees on the Judiciary arguing "that extending the term of copyright protection would impose substantial costs on the United States general public without supplying any public benefit. The extension bills represent a fundamental departure from the United States philosophy that intellectual property legislation serve a public purpose."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Karjala|first1=Dennis|title=Opposing Copyright Extension, Legislative Materials (105th Congress), Statement of Copyright and Intellectual Property Law Professors in Opposition to H.R. 604, H.R. 2589, and S.505|url=http://homepages.law.asu.edu/~dkarjala/OpposingCopyrightExtension/legmats/1998statement.html|accessdate=22 August 2015}}</ref>
An editorial in ''[[The New York Times]]'' argued against the copyright extension on February 21, 1998. The article stated "When Senator Hatch laments that [[George Gershwin]]'s ''[[Rhapsody in Blue]]'' will soon 'fall into the public domain,' he makes the public domain sound like a dark abyss where songs go, never to be heard again. In fact, when a work enters the public domain it means the public can afford to use it freely, to give it new currency."<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=The New York Times |date=February 21, 1998 |title=Keeping Copyright in Balance |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/02/21/opinion/keeping-copyright-in-balance.html }}</ref>
Opponents of the ''Bono Act'' consider the legislation to be [[corporate welfare]] and have [[Eldred v. Ashcroft|tried (but failed)]] to have it declared [[unconstitutional]], claiming that such an act is not "necessary and proper" to accomplishing the Constitution's stated purpose of "promot[ing] the progress of science and useful arts".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/openlaw/eldredvashcroft/supct/amici/ip-lawprofs.pdf |title=BRIEF OF INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAW PROFESSORS AS AMICI CURIAE SUPPORTING PETITIONERS|format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-01-21}}</ref> They argue that most works bring most of the profits during the first few years and are pushed off the market by the publishers thereafter. Thus there is little economic incentive in extending the terms of copyrights except for the few owners of franchises that are wildly successful, such as Disney. They also point out that the [[Tenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Tenth Amendment]] can be construed as placing limits on the powers that Congress can gain from a treaty. More directly, they see two successive terms of approximately 20 years each (the [[Copyright Act of 1976]] and the Bono Act) as the beginning of a "slippery slope" toward a [[perpetual copyright]] term that nullifies the intended effect and violates the spirit of the "for limited times" language of the [[United States Constitution/Article One|United States Constitution, Article I]], section 8, clause 8.<ref name="United States Constitution">{{cite web|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/constitution/constitution.articlei.html |title=Cornell University Law School – United States Constitution |publisher=Law.cornell.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-01-21}}</ref>
Some opponents have questioned the proponents' life expectancy argument, making the comparison between the growth of copyright terms and the term of patents in relation to the growth of life expectancies. Life expectancies have risen from about 35 years in 1800 <ref name="Life Expectancies in 1800s">{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/life-expectancy |title=Life Expectancies in 1800s |publisher=Answers.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-21}}</ref> to 77.6 years in 2002.<ref name="Life Expectancies in 2000s">{{cite web |url=http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/20557.php |title=Life Expectancies in 20002 |publisher=Medical News Today |date= |accessdate=2011-01-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101219101307/http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/20557.php |archivedate=2010-12-19 |df= }}</ref> While copyright terms have increased threefold, from only 28 years total (under the [[Copyright Act of 1790]]), life expectancies have roughly doubled. Moreover, life expectancy statistics are skewed due to historically high infant mortality rates. Correcting for infant mortality, life expectancy has only increased by fifteen years between 1850 and 2000.<ref>http://www.infoplease.com/ipa/A0005140.html</ref> In addition, copyright terms have increased significantly since the 1790 act, but [[patent]] terms have not been extended in parallel, with 20-year terms of protection remaining the (presumably under the laws) adequate compensation for innovation in a technical field.<ref name="Patent Laws">{{cite web|url=http://www.uspto.gov/web/offices/pac/doc/general/index.html#laws |title=United States Patent and Trademark Office – General Information |publisher=Uspto.gov |date= |accessdate=2011-01-21}}</ref> Seventeen prominent economists, including [[Kenneth Arrow]], [[Ronald Coase]], and [[Milton Friedman]], submitted an [[amicus curiae|amicus brief]] opposing the bill when it was challenged in court. They argued that the [[discounting|discounted]] [[present value]] of the extension was only a 1% increase for newly created works, while the increase in [[transaction cost]]s created by extending the terms of old works would be very large and without any [[Marginalism|marginal]] benefit.<ref>{{cite web|title=BRIEF OF GEORGE A. AKERLOF, KENNETH J. ARROW, TIMOTHY F. BRESNAHAN, JAMES M. BUCHANAN, RONALD H. COASE, LINDA R. COHEN, MILTON FRIEDMAN, JERRY R. GREEN, ROBERT W. HAHN, THOMAS W. HAZLETT, C. SCOTT HEMPHILL, ROBERT E. LITAN, ROGER G. NOLL, RICHARD SCHMALENSEE, STEVEN SHAVELL, HAL R. VARIAN, AND RICHARD J. ZECKHAUSER AS AMICI CURIAE IN SUPPORT OF PETITIONERS|url=http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/openlaw/eldredvashcroft/supct/amici/economists.pdf|accessdate=22 August 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402164457/http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/openlaw/eldredvashcroft/supct/amici/economists.pdf|archivedate=2 April 2015}}</ref> According to [[Lawrence Lessig]], when asked to sign the brief, Friedman had originally insisted that "the word 'no-brainer' [appear] in it somewhere," but still agreed to sign it even though his condition was not met.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Lawrence Lessig|authorlink1=Lawrence Lessig|title="only if the word ‘no-brainer’ appears in it somewhere": RIP Milton Friedman|url=http://www.lessig.org/2006/11/only-if-the-word-nobrainer-app/|accessdate=22 August 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402150417/http://www.lessig.org/2006/11/only-if-the-word-nobrainer-app/|archivedate=2 April 2015|quote="No doubt the highpoint of the Eldred v. Ashcroft case was when I learned Friedman would sign our "Economists’ Brief": As it was reported to me, when asked, he responded: "Only if the world [sic] ‘no brainer’ appears in it somewhere." A reasonable man, he signed even though we couldn’t fit that word in."}}</ref>
Another argument against the CTEA is focused on the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] "because of the prospective and retrospective application of the CTEA."<ref name=":0" /> The plaintiffs in ''[[Eldred v. Reno]]'' believed that "the CTEA failed to sustain the intermediate level of scrutiny test afforded by the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] because the government did not have an 'important' interest to justify withholding speech."<ref name=":0" />
Opponents also argue that the Act encourages "offshore production." For example, derivative works could be created outside the United States in areas where copyright would have expired, and that US law would prohibit these works to US residents. For example, a movie of Mickey Mouse playing with a computer could be legally created in Russia, but the movie would be refused admission for importation by US Customs because of copyright, resulting in a deprivation to American children. Similarly, the first [[Winnie-the-Pooh]] book was published in 1926 and would have been public domain in 2001.<ref name="Winnie the Pooh">{{cite web|last=Macavinta |first=Courtney |url=http://news.cnet.com/Copyright-extension-law-at-issue-in-suit/2100-1023_3-220049.html |title=CNET – Copyright extension law |publisher=News.cnet.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lavasurfer.com/pooh-faq10.html |title=Winnie the Pooh – FAQ – Your Frequently Asked Questions X |publisher=Lavasurfer.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-21}}</ref>
Opponents identify another possible harm from copyright extension: loss of productive value of private collections of copyrighted works. A person who collected copyrighted works that would soon "go out of copyright," intending to re-release them on copyright expiration, lost the use of his capital expenditures for an additional 20 years when the Bono Act passed. This is part of the underlying argument in ''[[Eldred v. Ashcroft]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.salon.com/tech/feature/2002/02/21/web_copyright/index.html |title=Salon.com Technology | Mickey Mouse vs. The People |publisher=Archive.salon.com |date=2002-02-21 |accessdate=2011-01-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422054443/http://archive.salon.com/tech/feature/2002/02/21/web_copyright/index.html |archivedate=2009-04-22 |df= }}</ref> The Bono Act is thus perceived to add an instability to commerce and investment, areas which have a better legal theoretical basis than intellectual property, whose theory is of quite recent development and is often criticized as being a corporate chimera. Conceivably, if one had made such an investment and then produced a derivative work (or perhaps even re-released the work ''in ipse''), he could counter a suit made by the copyright holder by declaring that Congress had unconstitutionally made, [[ex post facto]], a restriction on the previously unrestricted.
[[Howard Besser]] questioned the proponents' argument that "new works would not be created", which implies that the goal of copyright is to make the creation of new works possible. However, the Framers of the United States Constitution evidently thought that unnecessary, instead restricting the goal of copyright to merely "promot[ing] the progress of science and useful arts". In fact, some works created under time-limited copyright would not be created under perpetual copyright because the creator of a distantly derivative work does not have the money and resources to find the owner of copyright in the original work and purchase a license, or the individual or privately held owner of copyright in the original work might refuse to license a use at any price (though a refusal to license may trigger a fair use safety valve). Thus they argue that a rich, continually replenished, public domain is necessary for continued artistic creation.<ref name="Besser 1998">[[Howard Besser]], [http://www.studiolo.org/IP/TTM/BESSER.htm ''The Erosion of Public Protection: Attacks on the concept of Fair Use''], Paper delivered at the Town Meeting on Copyright & Fair Use, College Art Association, Toronto, February 1998. Retrieved 2010-07-27.</ref>
=== March 25, 1998 House Debate ===
The House debated the Copyright Term Extension Act (House Resolution 390) on March 25, 1998.<ref>Congressional Record, Volume 144, 1998, H1456-H1483, March 25, 1998</ref> The term extension was almost completely supported, with only the mild criticism by [[Jim Sensenbrenner]] (Wisconsin) of "H.R. 2589 provides a very generous windfall to the entertainment industry by extending the term of copyright for an additional 20 years."<ref>Congressional Record, Volume 144, 1998, H1459</ref> He suggested that it could be balanced by adding provisions from the [[Fairness in Music Licensing Act]] (H.R. 789). [[Lloyd Doggett]] (Texas) called the 'Fairness in Music Licensing Act' the 'Music Theft Act' and claimed that it was a mechanism to "steal the intellectual property of thousands of small businesspeople who are song writers in this land."<ref>Congressional Record, Volume 144, 1998, H1457</ref> The majority of subsequent debate was over Sensenbrenner's House Amendment 532<ref>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.uscongress/legislation.105hamdt532 {{cite web|url=http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.uscongress/legislation.105hamdt532 |title=Handle Problem Report (Library of Congress) |publisher=Hdl.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> to the CTEA. This amendment was over details of allowing music from radio and television broadcasts in small businesses to be played without licensing fees. An amendment to Sensenbrenner's amendment was proposed by [[Bill McCollum]],.<ref>http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.uscongress/legislation.105hamdt533 {{cite web|url=http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.uscongress/legislation.105hamdt533 |title=Handle Problem Report (Library of Congress) |publisher=Hdl.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> The key differences between Sensenbrenner's proposal and McCollum's amendment were 1) local arbitration versus court lawsuits in rate disagreements, 2) all retail businesses versus only restaurants and bars, 3) 3500 square feet of general public area versus {{convert|3500|sqft|m2}} of gross area, 4) which music licensing societies it applied to (all versus ASCAP and BMI), and 5) freedom from vicarious liability for landlords and others leasing space versus no such provision.<ref>Congressional Record, Volume 144, 1998, H1470-H1471</ref> After debate (and the first verse of American Pie<ref>Congressional Record, Volume 144, 1998, H1471</ref>) the McCollum Amendment was rejected in by 259 to 150<ref>Congressional Record, Volume 144, 1998, H1482</ref> and the Sensenbrenner amendment was passed by 297 to 112.<ref>Congressional Record, Volume 144, 1998, H1482-H1483</ref> The Copyright Term Extension Act H.R. 2589 was passed.<ref>Congressional Record, Volume 144, 1998, H1483</ref>
The term extension was supported for two key reasons. First, "copyright industries give us [(the United States)] one of our most significant trade surpluses." Second, the recently enacted legislation in the European Union had extended copyright there for 20 years, and so EU works would be protected for 20 years longer than US works if the US did not enact similar term extensions. [[Howard Coble]] also stated that it was good for consumers since "When works are protected by copyright, they attract investors who can exploit the work for profit."<ref>Congressional Record, Volume 144, 1998, Coble, North Carolina, H1458</ref> The term extension portion was supported by [[Songwriters Guild of America]], [[National Academy of Songwriters]], the [[Motion Picture Association of America]], the Intellectual Property Law Section of the American Bar Association, the [[Recording Industry Association of America]], [[National Music Publishers Association]], the [[Information Technology Association of America]] and others.<ref>Congressional Record, Volume 144, 1998, H1463</ref>
== Challenges ==
===Legal=== Publishers and librarians, among others, brought a lawsuit, ''[[Eldred v. Ashcroft]]'', to obtain an injunction on enforcement of the act. Oral arguments were heard by the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]] on October 9, 2002. On January 15, 2003 the court held the CTEA constitutional by a 7–2 decision.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/the-switch/wp/2013/10/25/15-years-ago-congress-kept-mickey-mouse-out-of-the-public-domain-will-they-do-it-again/ |author= Timothy B. Lee|work=Washington Post |date=October 25, 2013 |title=15 years ago, Congress kept Mickey Mouse out of the public domain. Will they do it again?}}</ref>
In 2003, the plaintiffs in the ''Eldred'' case began to shift their effort toward the U.S. Congress in support of a bill called the [[Public Domain Enhancement Act]] that would make the provisions of the Bono Act apply only to copyrights that had been registered with the [[Library of Congress]].
===Empirical testing=== In 2012, law professors Christopher Buccafusco and Paul J. Heald performed tests of three key justifications of copyright extension, namely: that public domain works will be underutilized and less available, will be oversaturated by poor quality copies, and poor quality derivative works will harm the reputation of the original works. They compared works from the two decades surrounding 1923 made available as audiobooks. They found that copyrighted works were available at a significantly lower rate than public domain ones, found no evidence of overexploitation driving down the price of works, and that the quality of the audiobook recordings did not significantly affect the price people were willing to pay for the books in print.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Buccafusco |first1=Christopher |last2=Heald |first2=Paul J. |date=2012-08-15 |title=Do Bad Things Happen When Works Enter the Public Domain?: Empirical Tests of Copyright Term Extension |journal=Berkeley Technology Law Journal |volume= |issue= |pages= |doi= |ssrn=2130008 }}</ref> Heald's later experiment analyzing a random sample of newly-posted works on [[Amazon.com]] revealed that public domain works from 1880 were posted at double the rate of copyrighted works from 1980.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Heald |first1=Paul J. |date=2013-07-05 |title=How Copyright Keeps Works Disappeared |journal= University of Illinois, Public Law & Legal Theory, Research Paper Series |volume= |issue= |pages= |doi= |ssrn=2290181 }}</ref>
